page.title: Objectives
page.content:
This lesson offers basic information on the new Advanced Distributed Learning (ADL) specification known as the Experience Application Protocol Interface, or xAPI. It is intended to familiarize CTC learning professionals with this new specification so as the abillity to utilize xAPI grows within the learning industry, CTC learning professionals are prepared to use it. 

Upon completion of this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Describe ADL's basic intent in developing the xAPI.
  • Recognize the benefits the xAPI offers learning professionals in designing and developing robust learning experiences.

page.title: What is the xAPI (previously called Tin Can API)?
page.content: An API is a set of programming instructions (or language) that two software programs or databases use to communicate (establishes software-to-software interfaces). Two examples are presented in the tabs below to better help you understand this concept.
page.tab: Internet shoppers use a ticket site (Fandango) to search all local movie theatres to find a movie and specific movie time. When the user selects a specific movie playing at a specific theatre (Digiplex), a selection from the Fandango site ignites the Fandango API to talk directly to the Digiplex website. The Fandango API allows tickets to be reserved and credit card information to be exchanged in order for the purchase to process. This could happen with any theatres’ website that has utilized the Fandango API (Cinema Center, Cinemark, or AMC Theatres).

A user accesses a website (i.e., a newspaper called "The Eagle") that requires an account.  The user can sign into The Eagle's website by either creating a new account or using an existing account such as Facebook or Twitter. When the user decides to use her existing Twitter account, this action ignites the use of the Twitter API that communicates with The Eagle's website allowing the user's Twitter account to gain access to the new website.

page.title: What are the differences between xAPI and SCORM?
page.content:
The SCORM API is used to track specific information like course completion, time spent taking a course, completion date, and post-test scores. This works well for tracking learners who are taking distance learning (DL) course launched from an LMS. The primary interaction tracked by SCORM is success or failure on a post-test. SCORM limits the instructional designers to creating DL courses and comes with the following limitations:

  • Courses are stored and launched from an LMS.
  • Students must have an internet connection. No Internet means no access to the course, no progress on learning, and no tracking.

Experience API is used to track all kinds of learning activities that ultimately can create a diverse, robust learning experience (notice here the term "learning experience is used and not DL course). xAPI provides a level of flexibility that SCORM was not capable of providing.  One key difference from SCORM is that xAPI does not require a LMS nor does it require constant access to the Internet.

Using xAPI, all learning activities can be collected by a new database called a Learning Record Store (LRS). LRSs are currently stand-alone products, but ADL predicts they will eventually be integrated directly into a LMS. A LRS is where xAPI sends all the data from any learning source a student accesses.  Therefore, learning activities can be tracked from a variety of informal and self-guided activities such as: mobile apps, social conversations / interactions, online videos, webcasts, podcasts, websites, Wikipedia, Youtube, TED Talks, Coursera, Kahn Academy, etc.

Since Experience API does not need the LMS to report activity, informal learning activities can all be integrated into formal courses creating a rich learning experience (or learning environment). Progress from these sources can be reported in the LMS or the LRS right alongside formal courses.

branch.title: Who Uses the xAPI?
branch.content:
All learning professionals can use the xAPI - Instructional Designers, Courseware Developers, Software Engineers, LMS designers, etc. Obviously depending on your job position, you will use xAPI differently. Software developers will use the API to virtually connect learning activities to the LRS. Instructional designers will design learning activities, or can chose existing learning activities, as part of a larger learning experience; ISDs can design these robust learning experiences whether their final training product resides inside of or outside of LMSs because they know the learning activity can be tracked and accounted for by the LRS. 

Click the "xAPI Learning Experience Example" button below to read a short scenario in which you, as a CTC employee, may be asked to use the xAPI.
branch.caption: My Caption

branch.title: xAPI Learning Experience Example
branch.content: CTC is contracted by a government agency to educate it’s entry-level Information Technology (IT) workforce on the advances made with high-speed routers, range extenders, and personal cloud space. You no longer are limited to creating a DL course with three lessons on each of these topics. You now create a comprehensive learning experience that includes a DL course, but also includes sending students outside of the LMS to view three YouTube videos, an 'Eli the Computer Guy' mini-course, and to perform independent research on each of these topics that ALL can be tracked and recorded by the LRS.
branch.caption: My Caption

page.title: How Does xAPI Affect DL Course Design?
page.content: The xAPI really does not affect “traditional: DL course design. However, if an ISD decides to direct a learner to a learning activity that resides outside of a DL course, the instruction has indeed changed  due in part because xAPI allows those external learning activities to be tracked. Again, it is important to think outside of traditional DL courses and begin to recognize the potential of using informal learning activities located outside of LMSs (or outside of standard DL course).  For CTC ISDs,  once Cognizen has the xAPI integrated, it will be during course publishing that the xAPI will be applied; therefore ISDs now have a choice to design DL courses exactly as they have been designed for year or to create rich learning experiences utilizing multiple sources that can be tracked via the xAPI .
page.sidebar:
Keep in mind...

The xAPI is meant to track all learning activities, not just DL courses, so informal learning experiences can be tracked just like formal learning experiences. Any learning activities that will be created outside of Cognizen should be discussed between the ISD, the courseware developer and/or a software engineer so a client’s desire to have the activity tracked utilizing the xAPI is known upfront and can be properly planned for by the team.

branch.title: Where does xAPI Reside (in a course, courseware development tool, an LMS, etc.)?
branch.content:
Really, everywhere. Remember, an API is a language two software programs or databases use to talk to one another.  Therefore, a DL course can use xAPI to talk to an LMS. Any learning activity can use and be tracked by the xAPI and then “recorded” by the LRS.

xAPI  reached version 1.0 in May 2013. However, LMS vendors have to incorporate the API specification for it to be used by companies that house all training records (or at least all DL) inside of an LMS. However, like any new technology, allowing its use is one thing but actually taking full advantage of the new technology is quite another.  There are authoring tools, such as such as Lectora, Articulate, and soon even Cognizen that support xAPI. However, for now, since the outputs of these tools (DL courseware) is almost always housed inside of an LMS, all that has really happened is that these tools have added xAPI as a publishing option much like publishing SCORM conformant courseware is an option. This causes some redundancy since the DL you create, which can already be tracked by SCORM, is now also tracked via xAPI. In essence, nothing additional is actually being tracked. 

Click the "1080p TV vs 4k TV Example" button below for a simplified example using TV technology to help you make sense of where xAPI really stands when all parties have not implemented the specification yet.
branch.caption: My Caption

branch.title: 1080p TV vs 4K TV Example
branch.content:
Think of SCORM as a 1080p TV. It is great and your TV's picture is beautiful. Nevertheless one afternoon you decide to go into your local Best Buy Store and you see a 4K TV (xAPI) sitting right next to a 1080p TV…. You can’t believe the difference in how striking the lines on a football field look on the 4K TV versus the 1080p TV.

So of course, you purchase a 4K TV, take it home, set it up and start watching your favorite sports team… BUT WAIT.  The picture on your new 4k TV is no different from the 1080p TV you just moved to your garage.

Truth is, you will not get that amazing 4K picture until your cable / satellite provider starts to broadcast using a 4K signal – in other words, the signal into your house is still 1080p.  Don’t worry, you can set up a Netflix account and purchase numerous 4K movies and get that awesome picture you were hoping for when you bought this new 4K TV!

xAPI works the same way as the 4k TV... until all the players (LMS vendors, courseware tools, instructional designers, etc.) utilize the specification, you won't get the full xAPI experience.
branch.caption: My Caption

page.title: When Should You Use the xAPI?
page.content:
As soon as you have access to a LRS you can begin using the xAPI.  It will be helpful if you also have access to courseware development tools that utilize the xAPI and, if still used by your client, access to a LMS that has also integrated the xAPI.

Once a LMS vendor incorporates xAPI, and you design a learning experience that includes more than just a DL courses (i.e, one that includes tracking leaning activities like social interactions and mobile mini-courses), you will be closer to fulfilling the potential of xAPI…. However, this scenario still does not achieve the complete intended purpose of xAPI, which includes interpreting the new data being collected from these additional learning activities.

page.title: How Does This “Advanced” Tracking and Interpreting Occur?
page.content: The data collected is only as good as the ability of the system collecting the data to interpret it. Therefore, though xAPI can track and record any learning activities, LMS vendors now need to upgrade their capabilities by adding robust analytics, reporting, and data visualization.
page.caption: Traditional DL versus Robust Learning Experience

page.title: So, Why Should You Use the xAPI?
page.content: The answer is simple:  To provide a richer, more inclusive learning experience for your students. The question really is not whether or not to use xAPI, the question is, "why provide training that adheres to yesterday’s standards when you can provide training that adheres to today / tomorrow’s standards?"
page.sidebar:
Remember...

You are training the future of our military and government personnel, so you should always want to train using the latest and greatest technologies available. Young learners today expect seamless training experiences that do not box them into any particular environment – xAPI does just that, provides the means for a seamless, all-inclusive learning experience.

page.title: Conclusion
page.content: Though the xAPI provides learning professionals with the ability to create more engaging learning environments that incorporate formal DL courses with informal learning activities, the learning industry still has a long way to go before it realizes the full potential of this new specification. The technology the learning industry is currently using to produce, distribute, administer and manage educational solutions works well for standard LMS-based DL, but going beyond that, the industry has quite a bit of catching up to do.  Moving to a modern DL environment will require learning technology vendors to commit a substantial amount of time and financial investment to achieve this end-state. Undoubtedly, xAPI-compliant LMSs will hit the market soon, but a LMS that truly takes advantage of all that the xAPI offers will likely not be available for quite some time. Nonetheless, xAPI is a significant advancement for the learning industry that provides the ability to measure, track and record robust learning experiences.
